misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No clear notional-machine misconception evident (code matches task)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that: (1) printing a prompt will tell the user what to type, (2) Scanner.nextDouble() will read the three numbers in the order typed, (3) assigning (v1 - v0) / t to a will compute acceleration once at that moment, and (4) concatenating a with a string will print the numeric result.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There isn’t an obvious gap here: this is essentially the correct Java execution model for this problem. The prompt string is for the human (not the computer), variables do not auto-update (but the student doesn’t rely on auto-updates), Java arithmetic uses the expected operators for this formula, and Scanner doesn’t modify previous variables in surprising ways. The only subtle conceptual issue that could arise (but isn’t shown as a mistake) is thinking the prompt affects input parsing; in Java it doesn’t—prompting and reading are separate actions.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; program should compile and produce correct output for valid numeric input. Potential runtime issue only if t == 0 (division by zero yields Infinity in double) or if non-numeric input is entered (InputMismatchException), but these are not misconceptions clearly evidenced by the code as written.
